title: Gary Hogeboom
text:
Gary Keith Hogeboom (born August 21, 1958) is an American former <a href="American%20football">football</a> <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a>, real estate developer, and television personality. He played in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>, <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> and <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Phoenix Cardinals</a>. Hogeboom played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Central%20Michigan%20University">Central Michigan University</a>. He was a contestant on the <a href="CBS">CBS</a> reality TV show "".
Early years.
Hogeboom attended <a href="Northview%20High%20School%20%28Grand%20Rapids%2C%20Michigan%29">Northview High School</a>, where he practiced football and <a href="basketball">basketball</a>. He accepted a football scholarship from <a href="Central%20Michigan%20University">Central Michigan University</a>.
As a junior in 1978, he became the starter at <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> in a <a href="triple%20option">triple-option wishbone offense</a>, registering 1,095 passing yards, 5 passing touchdowns, 329 rushing yards and 5 rushing touchdowns, while contributing to a 9–2 record. The next year, he posted 1,404 passing yards, 9 passing touchdowns, 417 rushing yards and 9 rushing touchdowns, leading his team to the school's first <a href="Mid-American%20Conference">Mid-American Conference</a> title with a 10–0–1 record.
He finished his career with 3,088 passing yards, 19 passing touchdowns, 957 rushing yards and 16 rushing touchdowns. He had a 19–2–1 records in his 2 seasons as a starter. In total he won 24 games in 28 starts. At the time, he was the school's All-time leader in <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> passes (19), total offense yards (4,045 yards), pass completions (208), career passing yards (3,088) and was ranked third in passing yards for a season (1,404).
In 1989, he was inducted into the Central Michigan Athletics Hall Of Fame. In 1994, he was inducted into the <a href="Mid-American%20Conference">Mid-American Conference</a> Sports Hall of Fame. In 2000, he was inducted into the Grand Rapids Sports Hall of Fame.
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
Hogeboom was <a href="NFL%20Draft">selected</a> by the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> in the fifth round (133rd overall) of the <a href="1980%20NFL%20Draft">1980 NFL Draft</a>. As a rookie, he earned a roster spot following the retirement of <a href="Roger%20Staubach">Roger Staubach</a>. He was the third-string quarterback in his first 2 seasons.
1982 season.
In <a href="1982%20NFL%20season">1982</a>, he passed <a href="Glenn%20Carano">Glenn Carano</a> on the depth chart for the backup quarterback role behind <a href="Danny%20White">Danny White</a>. In the 1982 NFC title game against the <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a>, he replaced a concussed White at the start of the second half and helped the team get back in the contest with 2 consecutive scoring drives, until making two critical interceptions, one returned by <a href="Darryl%20Grant">Darryl Grant</a> for a <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> that sealed the 31–17 loss. He completed 14 out of 29 attempts for 162 yards, 2 touchdowns and 2 interceptions. He began to garner attention and opened some eyes from Cowboys coaches and players alike with this performance.
1983 season.
Prior to the <a href="1983%20NFL%20season">1983 season</a>, the Cowboy players and fans began to lobby for Hogeboom to be the starting quarterback. White had led the team to three straight NFC Championship game appearances after taking over for <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Hall of Famer</a> <a href="Roger%20Staubach">Roger Staubach</a>, but couldn't win a <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a>. The players also felt that White had betrayed them because of his public support for the NFL team owners during the <a href="1982%20NFL%20season">1982 NFL players strike</a>. Furthermore, White was seen as quiet and standoffish, unlike the more vocal and personable Hogeboom.
The team gave Hogeboom more playing time in the pre-season, where he completed 42 out of 74 attempts for 475 yards, 4 touchdowns, 3 interceptions and a 77.1 quarterback rating.
White responded to the criticism by having his best statistical season ever in 1983 and leading the Cowboys to a 12–2 record going into a home matchup against the Redskins. However, the Cowboys were beaten at home by a score of 31–10, and the Redskins would go on to finish the season at 14–2, and reach their second straight <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a>. The Cowboys, meanwhile, would lose soundly 42–17 the next week to the <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a> on <a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>, and then lose 24–17 in the wildcard playoff game at home against the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a>. The rumblings for White to be benched got stronger and Hogeboom also began demanding to be traded.
1984 season.
In the <a href="1984%20NFL%20season">1984 pre-season</a>, Hogeboom completed 18 out of 32 attempts for 255 yards, one touchdown and no interceptions, compared to White's 
46 out of 83 attempts for 609 yards, 3 touchdowns and 4 interceptions.
On August 28, he was named the starter during a press conference where head coach <a href="Tom%20Landry">Tom Landry</a> began by announcing that <a href="offensive%20tackle">offensive tackle</a> <a href="Phil%20Pozderac">Phil Pozderac</a> would be the starter, only to catch the error and mispronounce the last name by saying "Hogenbloom".
Hogeboom started out well, completing 33 passes (club record) for 343 yards and one touchdown in a season opening win on Monday night on national TV against the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a>. However, in the next game against the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a>, <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a> <a href="Lawrence%20Taylor">Lawrence Taylor</a> sacked him four times and the Cowboys lost, 28–7. Despite the Cowboys 5–3 record, White relieved Hogeboom three games in a row, so Landry went back to the more experienced White against the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> and <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a>.
After a poor performance by both quarterbacks against the Giants, Hogeboom regained the starting position. The constant change at quarterback didn't help to improve the team's inconsistent play, eventually resulting in a 14–3 loss to the previously winless <a href="Buffalo%20Bills">Buffalo Bills</a>. White would go on to start the last 4 games, putting an end to one of the most famous quarterback controversies in <a href="NFL">NFL</a> history. Hogeboom produced a 6–4 record in 10 starts, posting 2,366 passing yards, 7 touchdowns and 14 interceptions.
1985 season.
In <a href="1985%20NFL%20season">1985</a>, he started 2 contests and played in parts of 3 others, substituting an injured White. Hogeboom lost 2 contests, completing 70 passes for 978 yards, 5 touchdowns and 7 interceptions.
On April 28, <a href="1986%20NFL%20season">1986</a>, he was traded to the Colts in exchange for switching positions in the second round of the <a href="1986%20NFL%20Draft">1986 NFL Draft</a> and a conditional draft choice (not exercised). With the Colts' 2nd-round pick, the Cowboys selected <a href="Darryl%20Clack">Darryl Clack</a>, and with the Cowboys' 2nd-round pick, the Colts selected <a href="Jack%20Trudeau">Jack Trudeau</a>.
Indianapolis Colts.
1986 season.
After acquiring Hogeboom the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> traded <a href="Mike%20Pagel">Mike Pagel</a>, who had been the previous starter at quarterback, to the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a> for a ninth round pick (#247-Bob Ontko) in the <a href="1987%20NFL%20Draft">1987 NFL Draft</a>.
The excitement was high at Hogeboom's arrival, as the franchise had not seen quality quarterback play since the days of <a href="Bert%20Jones">Bert Jones</a>. It was thought that giving head coach <a href="Rod%20Dowhower">Rod Dowhower</a> something to work with would yield great results, as he made his name with the <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> where he helped develop <a href="Neil%20Lomax">Neil Lomax</a>.
The Colts got off to a shaky start losing in New England 33–3. The next week against the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a>, the Colts lost both the game and Hogeboom, when he was injured after picking up an <a href="Albert%20Bentley">Albert Bentley</a> fumble and being tackled by Dolphin's safety <a href="Lyle%20Blackwood">Lyle Blackwood</a> at the end of a 50-yard run. On the play Hogeboom had the opportunity to run safely out of bounds, but instead tried to gain additional yards. Blackwood physically picked Hogeboom up and drove him into the ground, causing a serious right (throwing) shoulder separation. Colts General Manager <a href="Jim%20Irsay">Jim Irsay</a> had this to say of the tackle: "The way it looked on TV, it was a malicious tackle," "If that's the case, I think a player should be suspended. You're talking about knocking out a team's starting quarterback."
Hogeboom was assumed to be lost for the season and rookie <a href="Jack%20Trudeau">Jack Trudeau</a> was forced into the starting lineup and the team struggled through the season with thirteen straight losses. After the last loss, Dowhower was fired and former <a href="Southern%20Methodist%20University">Southern Methodist University</a> and <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a> coach <a href="Ron%20Meyer">Ron Meyer</a> was brought in.
Hogeboom surprised everyone by returning and starting for Meyer's first game as the Colts coach. They were matched against the <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a> and were a heavy underdog, Hogeboom played a great game helping the Colts come from behind to win on a blocked punt at the end of the fourth quarter. The Colts shocked the league by winning the last three games of the season to finish up at 3–13 and generating optimism heading into the next season.
1987 season.
With a potential player strike looming, the Colts started the <a href="1987%20NFL%20season">1987 season</a> with two losses, one was with <a href="Jack%20Trudeau">Jack Trudeau</a> who was replacing an injured Hogeboom. At this point the NFL Players Association chose to call a work stoppage and Hogeboom was one of the handful of players who chose to cross the picket lines and keep playing. At issue was specific language in Hogeboom's contract which potentially could have cost him all his remaining salary.
The owners decided to field teams of replacement players to fulfill their obligation to the ticket holders and television networks. Hogeboom led the Colts replacement players to a 2–0 record before being injured in the second game. This injury was caused by veteran defensive end <a href="Marty%20Lyons">Marty Lyons</a> flagrantly spearing him on a quarterback sneak play, breaking a rib in his back and puncturing a lung. Although the Colts lost the last strike game with a new quarterback, the victories in the previous contests were crucial in securing the franchise's first playoff berth in ten years.
After the strike, <a href="Jack%20Trudeau">Jack Trudeau</a> started the next four games with a 2–2 record. After a win against the <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a>, the Colts made a blockbuster trade to get star running back <a href="Eric%20Dickerson">Eric Dickerson</a>. Since Hogeboom's injury had healed, he was re-inserted as the starter, helping the team win against the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a>, but also lost against the <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a>. In the next game, he led the Colts to a rousing home win versus the <a href="Houston%20Oilers">Houston Oilers</a>. However, Hogeboom was to again be injured in this game. On a 22-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Albert%20Bentley">Albert Bentley</a>, Hogeboom was struck on the inside part of his throwing arm by a blitzing <a href="Jeff%20Donaldson%20%28American%20football%29">Jeff Donaldson</a>. This blow drove his arm up in an unnatural way, dislocating his right shoulder and sending him to the <a href="injured%20reserve%20list">injured reserve list</a>.
<a href="Jack%20Trudeau">Jack Trudeau</a> would finish out the season as the starter, taking the Colts to their first playoff game since <a href="1977%20NFL%20season">1977</a>, which they would lose 21–38 against the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>.
1988 season.
Although he started in the season opener and completed 15 out of 20 passes, he was demoted to third-string quarterback with rookie <a href="Chris%20Chandler">Chris Chandler</a> earning the starter job.
Against the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a>, coach Meyer unveiled the <a href="triple%20option">wishbone offense</a>, in which Hogeboom would be used on occasions during the season. He also came off the bench for an injured Chandler, to lead the team to a 17–14 win against the <a href="Buffalo%20Bills">Buffalo Bills</a>. At the end of the year, he was left unprotected—eligible to sign with any team that wanted him—under <a href="Plan%20B%20free%20agency">Plan B free agency</a>.
Phoenix Cardinals.
On March 3, <a href="1989%20NFL%20season">1989</a>, he was signed as a <a href="Plan%20B%20free%20agency">Plan B free agent</a> with the <a href="Phoenix%20Cardinals">Phoenix Cardinals</a>, reuniting with head coach and former Cowboys assistant <a href="Gene%20Stallings">Gene Stallings</a>. He also was the highest signed player with four-year $3.27 million contract and a $250,000 signing bonus.
He was acquired because of <a href="Neil%20Lomax">Neil Lomax</a>'s problematic arthritic left hip, which eventually forced him to retire. Hogeboom was named the starter and posted career highs with 2,591 passing yards, 14 touchdowns and 19 interceptions, but finished with a 5–8 record. The next year <a href="Joe%20Bugel">Joe Bugel</a> was hired as the new head coach and Hogeboom was waived on September 3, <a href="1990%20NFL%20season">1990</a>.
Washington Redskins.
On September 23, <a href="1990%20NFL%20season">1990</a>, he signed as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> with the <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a> for depth purposes after <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> <a href="Mark%20Rypien">Mark Rypien</a> was injured. He was released on December 28 to make room for <a href="defensive%20tackle">defensive tackle</a> <a href="Tracy%20Rocker">Tracy Rocker</a>.
Hogeboom played for eleven seasons (1980–1990) and passed for 9,346 yards, 49 touchdowns and 60 interceptions, along with 164 rushing yards and 4 rushing touchdowns.
"Survivor".
In 2005, Hogeboom was a contestant on "", the 11th season of the <a href="CBS">CBS</a> reality TV show "<a href="Survivor%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">Survivor</a>". He kept his professional sports past a secret and even sneakily claimed that he was a <a href="landscaper">landscaper</a> named Gary Hawkins. He did this out of fear that he would be eliminated right away if the other competitors assumed he was already wealthy, being a former NFL quarterback. Unfortunately for him, his plan failed when another contestant, <a href="Danni%20Boatwright">Danni Boatwright</a>, who worked in sports radio, recognized him immediately. Despite this confrontation between the two, Danni would be Gary's closest ally throughout the game. In fact, post-show interviews from other contestants revealed that they actually all knew his real identity but didn't care, because he was a strong, well-liked player.
Hogeboom was eliminated on Day 30 and became the third jury member, after saving himself from elimination by using the hidden <a href="Immunity%20%28reality%20television%29">immunity</a> idol at a previous Tribal Council; his elimination was unrelated to the issue of his true identity, simply coming down to the powerful alliance of <a href="Rafe%20Judkins">Rafe Judkins</a>, <a href="Stephenie%20LaGrossa">Stephenie LaGrossa</a>, Cindy Hall, Lydia Morales, and Judd Sergeant voting off non-alliance members. After Hogeboom was voted out, he confessed in his final words that his name was Gary Hogeboom and he was an ex-NFL quarterback. He went down in "Survivor" history as the first person to ever find and play a hidden immunity idol at Tribal Council.
Personal life.
Hogeboom is married with four children. He lives in <a href="Grand%20Haven%2C%20Michigan">Grand Haven, Michigan</a> where he is a private <a href="real%20estate%20developer">real estate developer</a>. He also coaches the JV Girls basketball team at Grand Haven High School.
